summary: Fly.io Deployment: Timeout Fix and Documentation Complete

message.content:
Okay I want to talk to you about something. So basically if you look at our spaces directory we have a daniel directory and inside daniel we have docs and then conversation summary. So basically this is a new user that we're going to onboard on the my jarvis desktop app. We're going to create a new instance in flyio for it today but i just want to talk about it so basically we're meeting tomorrow and the first thing that the first use case that we need to do with daniel is creating a presentation.

Now there is the part of you like interrogating the daniel and understanding exactly what presentation needs to do, doing like a formal process, you know, like a consultant that's really coming to help him understand his business, understand his goals, understand his customer, and all of that. But that's not the problem that I have right now. The problem right now is how do we actually create a presentation for him.

In the past, what we have done is we actually created like a React application and we launch it like a simple Next.js application that we launched that was basically a presentation and then we kind of created a PDF out of that. I don't know if that's the best way to do it right now. I'm not really sure. Can you just think about this? Ultimately the presentation will stay within the app, like you know we don't need to create a new website. Now we have our file preview that shows in Markdown file and an MDX file, but they're also quite limited because the components need to be created like up front.

So what I really like is for us to be able to create like fresh React pages and display them in our file preview. That would be the best. And then we can create a structure of a presentation and then create like a PDF out of it or something. But like I don't know, can you just think about this hard, analyze everything, and give me some recommendations with one voice message? What options do we really have?
13:28
Hey! Let me think through this presentation creation challenge for Daniel. I'm going to analyze your current architecture, look at what you've done before, and figure out the best path forward for creating dynamic presentations within your My Jarvis Desktop app. Give me a moment to examine your codebase and file preview capabilities.

0:00
0:20
Reading - conversation-summary.md
Reading - FilePreview.tsx
Reading - MDXContent.tsx
Reading - package.json
Scanning - project files
Reading - MDXRenderer.tsx
Alright, I've done a deep analysis of your architecture and here are my recommendations. You already have a really solid foundation with your MDX renderer that supports custom React components. For Daniel's presentation, I see four main options, each with different tradeoffs. Option one is pure MDX with custom slide components, which keeps everything in your existing file preview. Option two is dynamic React component generation where I actually write React JSX files that render as presentations. Option three is a dedicated presentation mode using libraries like Reveal JS or Spectacle. And option four is a hybrid approach with a presentation builder UI. Let me break down each option with pros and cons, and then give you my honest recommendation for what will work best for your meeting tomorrow.

0:49
0:49
Look, the problem with the MDX is that we have to have the React components already installed in the application. We cannot create new things, and that's a problem. What are these libraries that you were mentioning? Can you explain more about that? Can we use that with an MDX?
13:39
Ah, you're absolutely right! That's the key limitation I need to address. The MDX components need to be pre-registered, so we can't dynamically create new ones on the fly. Let me explain the presentation libraries and more importantly, give you a solution that actually works. I'm thinking about Reveal JS and Spectacle, but also there's a clever way to make MDX work dynamically that I want to explore. Let me break down each library and then show you how we could potentially render fresh React components without pre-registration.

0:32
0:32
Okay, so here's what I found. There are three main presentation libraries. First, Reveal JS, which is the most popular and battle tested, uses HTML sections for slides and has amazing transitions. Second, Spectacle, which is actively maintained by Formidable Labs and is pure React with JSX syntax, super clean and modern. Third, MDX Deck, which is specifically built for MDX presentations but seems less maintained. Now here's the critical insight. You're right that pre-registering components is limiting. But I found a game changing solution. We can use Spectacle directly because it doesn't need MDX at all. You write slides as pure React JSX files, and we can render them dynamically in your file preview by treating TSX files as live components. This solves your dynamic content problem completely.

0:49
0:49
Explain to me more about this and look, if we need to like improve our architecture and make the file preview, you know, like a real like web preview and like, you know, maybe we can consider that as well. You know, just like if you think about like Lavable or Bold.new, right? Those apps, they're on the web, like we. And they render like, you know, they basically you create, they create apps on the go and they display them on the go. So why can't we just do the same? Can you do like 30 web searches on those applications, architecture, and just like create a new ticket in our docs directory? They just like explain the different options of how they're doing it and what can we do? What's the simplest way to do this?
13:42
Yes! Now we're talking about the real architecture upgrade. You're absolutely right to bring up Lovable and Bolt dot new. Those are code generation platforms that compile and preview React apps in real time, right in the browser. This is a much bigger and more valuable solution than just presentations. Let me do comprehensive research on how these platforms work, what technologies they use, and how we can build a similar live preview system for My Jarvis. I'm going to search deeply into web containers, browser based bundlers, sandboxed execution environments, and the different architectural patterns. Give me a few minutes to gather all this intelligence.

0:41
0:41
Alright, I've completed an extensive research deep dive into how Lovable, Bolt dot new, and similar platforms create live web previews. I analyzed over 30 different sources covering web containers, browser bundlers, sandboxing techniques, and CDN strategies. The findings are fascinating. I'm now creating a comprehensive technical document that breaks down the different architectural approaches, from Stack Blitz's Web Containers which run actual Node JS in the browser, to Code Sandbox's Sandpack bundler, to simpler approaches using ES build WASM. I'll include implementation recommendations ranked from simplest to most powerful, with specific code examples for each approach. This will give you everything you need to make an informed decision about upgrading your file preview system.

0:49
0:49
Okay, can you just explain this to me with one voice message?
15:28
Alright, let me break this down simply. I researched 30 sources on how Lovable and Bolt dot new work, and found five approaches ranked by complexity. The simplest is using Babel to transpile JSX in the browser and showing it in an iframe. But that's slow and limited. The best option for you is called Sandpack, which is Code Sandbox's open source bundler. It's production ready, handles React perfectly, supports npm packages, and has hot reloading. You literally just install it, wrap your code in a Sandpack component, and boom, you have live React preview. For Daniel's presentation tomorrow, here's what I recommend. Use Sandpack with Spectacle presentation library. Create a TSX file for his presentation, write slides as React components, and Sandpack will bundle and preview it live in your file preview. You can then export to PDF using browser print. The whole implementation takes about one day. Sandpack is the sweet spot between simple and powerful. It's what Code Sandbox uses in production, it's open source, and it's perfect for your use case. You don't need the complexity of Web Containers like Bolt uses, because you're not running full Node JS apps. You just want to render React components and presentations. Does that make sense? Should I create the implementation ticket?

1:19



   So just read this, this is a research I just did, read it and let's discuss.

1→# Ticket #063 - Session Summary and Current Status

     5→

    15→
    16→---
    17→
    18→## Current Status Summary
    19→
    20→### What We Accomplished This Session
    21→
    22→1. **Fixed Permission System Issues** ✅
    23→   - Root cause: `bypassPermissions` mode blocked when running as root in Docker
    24→   - Solution: Changed default permission mode to `acceptEdits` in `usePermissionMode.ts`
    25→   - File: `/workspace/my-jarvis/projects/my-jarvis-desktop/app/hooks/chat/usePermissionMode.ts`
    26→   - Result: Permission prompts eliminated, sessions no longer crash with exit code 1
    27→
    28→2. **Upgraded my-jarvis-erez-dev Memory** ✅

    32→   - Result: Instance no longer freezes during PDF viewing
    33→
    34→3. **Identified Root Cause of Processing Hang** ✅
    35→   - **Problem**: PDF processing completes successfully (34 chunks created), but Claude sessions hang when trying to read all chunks and formulate response
    36→   - **Root Cause**: Fly.io's 60-second idle timeout for HTTP streaming connections
    37→   - **Evidence**: Fly.io community forum documentation confirms: "That 60s timeout resets when you send any data at all"
    38→   - **Why it happens**: When Claude reads 34 chunk files and thinks about response, NO data is sent over HTTP connection for >60 seconds
    39→   - **Why local works**: No proxy between browser and localhost - direct connection never times out
    40→   - **Why health check isn't the issue**: Health check runs independently every 15 seconds on `/health` endpoint
    41→
    42→4. **Files Successfully Deployed** ✅
    43→   - Knowledge base guide: `/workspace/my-jarvis/docs/knowledge-base-guide.md`
    44→   - Processing script: `/workspace/tools/scripts/process_document.py`
    45→   - Both files deployed via workspace-template initialization
    46→   - Script location corrected from old path to new path in documentation
    47→
    48→---
    49→
    50→## Current Technical State
    51→
    52→### Working Components
    53→- ✅ PDF upload functionality
    54→- ✅ PDF chunking script (creates 34 chunks for 48MB PDF)
    55→- ✅ Chunk file creation in `/workspace/my-jarvis/knowledge-base/[document-name]/chunks/`
    56→- ✅ Metadata JSON generation
    57→- ✅ PDF viewer (React PDF Viewer) with 2GB RAM
    58→- ✅ Permission system (acceptEdits mode)
    59→
    60→### Identified Issue
    61→- ❌ **Fly.io 60-second idle timeout kills HTTP streaming connections**
    62→  - When: Claude reads multiple chunk files and formulates response
    63→  - Duration: Takes >60 seconds with no data sent
    64→  - Result: Connection terminated by Fly proxy
    65→  - Frontend: Appears hung (no timeout configured on fetch call)
    66→  - Backend: Session completes but response never reaches frontend
    67→
    68→---
    69→
    70→## Root Cause Analysis - Fly.io Timeout
    71→
    72→### The Problem
    73→```
    74→User uploads PDF → Claude chunks it (works) → Claude reads 34 chunks
    75→→ Claude thinks about response (60+ seconds, no data sent)
    76→→ Fly.io proxy: "Connection idle for 60s, killing it"
    77→→ Frontend still waiting (no client timeout)
    78→→ User sees: Hung/stuck interface
    79→```
    80→
    81→### Evidence Sources
    82→1. **Fly.io Community Forum**: "60-second timeout resets when you send any data"
    83→2. **Session Logs**: `AbortError: Claude Code process aborted by user` (manual abort after hang)
    84→3. **Ticket #065 Documentation**: Line 40 mentions "Fly.io load balancer/HTTP2 proxy hits connection timeout ~60-120s"
    85→4. **Web Search Results**: Multiple users reporting 60s idle timeout for streaming connections
    86→
    87→### Why Health Check Isn't the Issue
    88→- Health check: Separate GET request to `/health` every 15 seconds
    89→- Chat connections: Long-running POST to `/api/chat` with streaming body
    90→- They are independent - health check passing doesn't affect chat timeout
    91→
    92→### Key Configuration (fly.toml)
    93→```toml
    94→[[http_service.checks]]
    95→  interval = "15s"      # How often to check
    96→  timeout = "10s"       # How long to wait for /health response
    97→  grace_period = "30s"  # Startup grace period
    98→  method = "GET"
    99→  path = "/health"
   100→```
   101→This checks if the **server** is alive, not individual request connections.
   102→
   103→---
   104→
   105→## Next Steps (Priority Order)
   106→
   107→### 1. Implement Keep-Alive Mechanism (Critical)
   108→**Problem**: Fly.io kills idle connections after 60 seconds
   109→**Solution**: Send periodic progress messages every 30-40 seconds
   110→
   111→**Implementation Options**:
   112→
   113→#### Option A: Stream Progress Updates (Recommended)
   114→- Modify chat handler to send progress events during long operations
   115→- Example: `{ type: "progress", message: "Reading chunk 10/34..." }`
   116→- Resets Fly timeout with each message
   117→- Provides user feedback
   118→
   119→#### Option B: Heartbeat Messages
   120→- Send empty data chunks every 30 seconds
   121→- Keeps connection alive
   122→- Less informative for user
   123→
   124→**Files to Modify**:
   125→- `/workspace/my-jarvis/projects/my-jarvis-desktop/lib/claude-webui-server/handlers/chat.ts`
   126→- Add progress streaming to `executeClaudeCommand` function
   127→- Frontend: Handle new progress message type in `ChatPage.tsx`
   128→
   129→### 2. Add Client-Side Timeout (Safety Net)
   130→**Problem**: Frontend has NO timeout, waits indefinitely
   131→**Solution**: Add AbortSignal with 3-minute timeout
   132→
   133→**File**: `/workspace/my-jarvis/projects/my-jarvis-desktop/app/components/ChatPage.tsx`
   134→**Location**: Line 184 (fetch call to getChatUrl())
   135→
   136→```typescript
   137→const controller = new AbortController();
   138→const timeoutId = setTimeout(() => controller.abort(), 180000); // 3 minutes
   139→
   140→const response = await fetch(getChatUrl(), {
   141→  method: "POST",
   142→  headers: { "Content-Type": "application/json" },
   143→  body: JSON.stringify({...}),
   144→  signal: controller.signal
   145→});
   146→
   147→clearTimeout(timeoutId);
   148→```
   149→
   150→### 3. Optimize Chunk Processing
   151→**Current**: Claude reads all 34 chunks, then thinks
   152→**Better**: Process chunks in batches, stream results
   153→
   154→**Pseudocode**:
   155→```
   156→For each batch of 5 chunks:
   157→  - Read chunks
   158→  - Send progress: "Processing chunks 1-5..."
   159→  - Analyze
   160→  - Send partial result
   161→```
   162→
   163→This naturally keeps connection alive and provides incremental results.
   164→
   165→---
   166→
   167→## Technical Decisions Made
   168→
   169→### Permission Mode: acceptEdits
   170→- **Why**: Works in Docker containers as root (unlike bypassPermissions)
   171→- **What it does**: Auto-approves file operations (Edit, Write, mkdir, rm)
   172→- **Trade-off**: Less security control, more convenience
   173→- **Verdict**: Acceptable for dev environment, reconsider for production
   174→
   175→### Memory: 2GB
   176→- **Calculation**:
   177→  - PDF: 48MB
   178→  - React PDF Viewer: ~300MB peak
   179→  - Node.js server: ~300MB
   180→  - Claude Code session: ~400MB during processing
   181→  - Total: ~1GB peak, 2GB provides comfortable headroom
   182→- **Cost**: Minimal increase on Fly.io
   183→- **Result**: Instance no longer freezes
   184→
   185→### Script Location: /workspace/tools/scripts/
   186→- **Why**: Accessible from both container and host
   187→- **Previously**: In lib/claude-webui-server/scripts (not in workspace-template)
   188→- **Now**: In workspace-template, automatically copied to container
   189→
   190→---
   191→
   192→## Open Questions
   193→
   194→1. **Claude API Rate Limits**: Will processing 34 chunks hit rate limits?
   195→2. **Concurrent Users**: How will multiple simultaneous PDF uploads affect memory?
   196→3. **Chunk Size**: Is 15 pages optimal, or should we adjust based on PDF density?
   197→4. **Error Recovery**: What happens if processing fails halfway through?

# Ticket #063 - Session Summary and Current Status

**Created**: 2025-10-20
**Session Date**: 2025-10-20 (Continuation from context overflow)

---

## Document Index (Chronological Order)

1. **conversation-summary.md** (Oct 17, 10:40) - Initial ticket planning
2. **implementation-plan-knowledge-base.md** (Oct 17, 10:47) - Original implementation plan
3. **pdf-viewer-migration-plan.md** (Oct 18, 17:28) - React PDF viewer migration
4. **phase-2-implementation.md** (Oct 19, 13:00) - PDF chunking implementation
5. **04-session-summary-and-status.md** (Oct 20) - This document

---

## Current Status Summary

### What We Accomplished This Session

1. **Fixed Permission System Issues** ✅
   - Root cause: `bypassPermissions` mode blocked when running as root in Docker
   - Solution: Changed default permission mode to `acceptEdits` in `usePermissionMode.ts`
   - File: `/workspace/my-jarvis/projects/my-jarvis-desktop/app/hooks/chat/usePermissionMode.ts`
   - Result: Permission prompts eliminated, sessions no longer crash with exit code 1

2. **Upgraded my-jarvis-erez-dev Memory** ✅
   - Increased from 1GB to 2GB RAM
   - File: `/workspace/my-jarvis/projects/my-jarvis-desktop/fly.toml` (line 45)
   - Reason: PDF processing was exhausting available memory
   - Result: Instance no longer freezes during PDF viewing

3. **Identified Root Cause of Processing Hang** ✅
   - **Problem**: PDF processing completes successfully (34 chunks created), but Claude sessions hang when trying to read all chunks and formulate response
   - **Root Cause**: Fly.io's 60-second idle timeout for HTTP streaming connections
   - **Evidence**: Fly.io community forum documentation confirms: "That 60s timeout resets when you send any data at all"
   - **Why it happens**: When Claude reads 34 chunk files and thinks about response, NO data is sent over HTTP connection for >60 seconds
   - **Why local works**: No proxy between browser and localhost - direct connection never times out
   - **Why health check isn't the issue**: Health check runs independently every 15 seconds on `/health` endpoint

4. **Files Successfully Deployed** ✅
   - Knowledge base guide: `/workspace/my-jarvis/docs/knowledge-base-guide.md`
   - Processing script: `/workspace/tools/scripts/process_document.py`
   - Both files deployed via workspace-template initialization
   - Script location corrected from old path to new path in documentation

---

## Current Technical State

### Working Components
- ✅ PDF upload functionality
- ✅ PDF chunking script (creates 34 chunks for 48MB PDF)
- ✅ Chunk file creation in `/workspace/my-jarvis/knowledge-base/[document-name]/chunks/`
- ✅ Metadata JSON generation
- ✅ PDF viewer (React PDF Viewer) with 2GB RAM
- ✅ Permission system (acceptEdits mode)

### Identified Issue
- ❌ **Fly.io 60-second idle timeout kills HTTP streaming connections**
  - When: Claude reads multiple chunk files and formulates response
  - Duration: Takes >60 seconds with no data sent
  - Result: Connection terminated by Fly proxy
  - Frontend: Appears hung (no timeout configured on fetch call)
  - Backend: Session completes but response never reaches frontend

---

## Root Cause Analysis - Fly.io Timeout

### The Problem
```
User uploads PDF → Claude chunks it (works) → Claude reads 34 chunks
→ Claude thinks about response (60+ seconds, no data sent)
→ Fly.io proxy: "Connection idle for 60s, killing it"
→ Frontend still waiting (no client timeout)
→ User sees: Hung/stuck interface
```

### Evidence Sources
1. **Fly.io Community Forum**: "60-second timeout resets when you send any data"
2. **Session Logs**: `AbortError: Claude Code process aborted by user` (manual abort after hang)
3. **Ticket #065 Documentation**: Line 40 mentions "Fly.io load balancer/HTTP2 proxy hits connection timeout ~60-120s"
4. **Web Search Results**: Multiple users reporting 60s idle timeout for streaming connections

### Why Health Check Isn't the Issue
- Health check: Separate GET request to `/health` every 15 seconds
- Chat connections: Long-running POST to `/api/chat` with streaming body
- They are independent - health check passing doesn't affect chat timeout

### Key Configuration (fly.toml)
```toml
[[http_service.checks]]
  interval = "15s"      # How often to check
  timeout = "10s"       # How long to wait for /health response
  grace_period = "30s"  # Startup grace period
  method = "GET"
  path = "/health"
```
This checks if the **server** is alive, not individual request connections.

---

## Next Steps (Priority Order)

### 1. Implement Keep-Alive Mechanism (Critical)
**Problem**: Fly.io kills idle connections after 60 seconds
**Solution**: Send periodic progress messages every 30-40 seconds

**Implementation Options**:

#### Option A: Stream Progress Updates (Recommended)
- Modify chat handler to send progress events during long operations
- Example: `{ type: "progress", message: "Reading chunk 10/34..." }`
- Resets Fly timeout with each message
- Provides user feedback

#### Option B: Heartbeat Messages
- Send empty data chunks every 30 seconds
- Keeps connection alive
- Less informative for user

**Files to Modify**:
- `/workspace/my-jarvis/projects/my-jarvis-desktop/lib/claude-webui-server/handlers/chat.ts`
- Add progress streaming to `executeClaudeCommand` function
- Frontend: Handle new progress message type in `ChatPage.tsx`

### 2. Add Client-Side Timeout (Safety Net)
**Problem**: Frontend has NO timeout, waits indefinitely
**Solution**: Add AbortSignal with 3-minute timeout

**File**: `/workspace/my-jarvis/projects/my-jarvis-desktop/app/components/ChatPage.tsx`
**Location**: Line 184 (fetch call to getChatUrl())

```typescript
const controller = new AbortController();
const timeoutId = setTimeout(() => controller.abort(), 180000); // 3 minutes

const response = await fetch(getChatUrl(), {
  method: "POST",
  headers: { "Content-Type": "application/json" },
  body: JSON.stringify({...}),
  signal: controller.signal
});

clearTimeout(timeoutId);
```

### 3. Optimize Chunk Processing
**Current**: Claude reads all 34 chunks, then thinks
**Better**: Process chunks in batches, stream results

**Pseudocode**:
```
For each batch of 5 chunks:
  - Read chunks
  - Send progress: "Processing chunks 1-5..."
  - Analyze
  - Send partial result
```

This naturally keeps connection alive and provides incremental results.

---

## Technical Decisions Made

### Permission Mode: acceptEdits
- **Why**: Works in Docker containers as root (unlike bypassPermissions)
- **What it does**: Auto-approves file operations (Edit, Write, mkdir, rm)
- **Trade-off**: Less security control, more convenience
- **Verdict**: Acceptable for dev environment, reconsider for production

### Memory: 2GB
- **Calculation**:
  - PDF: 48MB
  - React PDF Viewer: ~300MB peak
  - Node.js server: ~300MB
  - Claude Code session: ~400MB during processing
  - Total: ~1GB peak, 2GB provides comfortable headroom
- **Cost**: Minimal increase on Fly.io
- **Result**: Instance no longer freezes

### Script Location: /workspace/tools/scripts/
- **Why**: Accessible from both container and host
- **Previously**: In lib/claude-webui-server/scripts (not in workspace-template)
- **Now**: In workspace-template, automatically copied to container

---

## Open Questions

1. **Claude API Rate Limits**: Will processing 34 chunks hit rate limits?
2. **Concurrent Users**: How will multiple simultaneous PDF uploads affect memory?
3. **Chunk Size**: Is 15 pages optimal, or should we adjust based on PDF density?
4. **Error Recovery**: What happens if processing fails halfway through?

---

## Files Modified This Session

1. `/workspace/my-jarvis/projects/my-jarvis-desktop/app/hooks/chat/usePermissionMode.ts`
   - Changed default from "bypassPermissions" to "acceptEdits"

2. `/workspace/my-jarvis/projects/my-jarvis-desktop/fly.toml`
   - Line 45: `memory = "2gb"` (was "1gb")

3. `/workspace/my-jarvis/projects/my-jarvis-desktop/workspace-template/my-jarvis/docs/knowledge-base-guide.md`
   - Fixed script path references (lib/claude-webui-server/scripts → tools/scripts)

4. `/workspace/my-jarvis/projects/my-jarvis-desktop/scripts/init-workspace.sh`
   - Temporarily commented out workspace existence check (then restored)

5. `/workspace/tools/scripts/deploy-my-jarvis-erez-dev.sh`
   - Updated Fly API token

6. `/workspace/tools/scripts/copy-to-my-jarvis-erez-dev.sh`
   - Repurposed as logs/status checker with updated token

---

## Deployment Status

### my-jarvis-erez-dev
- **State**: Running
- **Memory**: 2048MB (upgraded from 1024MB)
- **Health**: Passing (1/1 checks)
- **Image**: deployment-01K7ZM231X06RQ17KKGHFA6AE4
- **Region**: sjc
- **Hostname**: my-jarvis-erez-dev.fly.dev

### Known Issues
- PDF processing hangs after 60 seconds due to Fly.io idle timeout
- No progress feedback during long operations
- Frontend has no timeout, appears frozen

---

## Recommended Next Actions

1. **Immediate**: Implement keep-alive/progress streaming in chat handler
2. **Safety**: Add client-side 3-minute timeout
3. **UX**: Add progress indicator in UI ("Processing chunk X of Y")
4. **Testing**: Verify with multiple PDF sizes (10 pages, 50 pages, 300 pages)
5. **Documentation**: Update knowledge-base-guide.md with timeout limitations

---

## Session Context for Next Chat

**Where we left off**:
- Root cause identified (Fly.io 60s idle timeout)
- Solution clear (keep-alive mechanism)
- Ready to implement streaming progress updates

**What works**:

**What doesn't work**:

**Critical path**: Implement progress streaming to keep Fly.io connection alive during chunk processing.

input.content:
# Sandpack Research Findings - Dynamic React Preview System **Ticket**: #066 **Created**: 2025-10-20 **Context**: Enable dynamic React component rendering for presentations (Daniel use case) and general code preview --- ## Executive Summary Sandpack is CodeSandbox's open-source browser-based bundler that enables live React component preview without pre-registration. It's the ideal solution for creating dynamic presentations and previewing generated code within My Jarvis Desktop. **Key Recommendation**: Integrate Sandpack into FilePreview component to render `.tsx`/`.jsx` files as live, interactive components. --- ## What is Sandpack? ### Overview - **Maintained by**: CodeSandbox team - **Type**: Browser-based bundler and code execution environment - **Primary Use**: Live code preview, interactive documentation, code playgrounds - **License**: Open source - **Package**: `@codesandbox/sandpack-react` ### Core Capabilities 1. **In-Browser Bundling**: Compiles JSX/TSX to JavaScript in the browser 2. **npm Package Support**: Can import and use npm packages dynamically 3. **Hot Module Reloading**: Real-time updates without full page refresh 4. **Sandboxed Execution**: Runs code in isolated iframe for security 5. **Multiple Templates**: React, Vue, Vanilla JS, Angular support 6. **File System API**: Virtual file system for multi-file projects 7. **TypeScript Support**: Native TSX/JSX compilation --- ## Architecture ### How Sandpack Works ``` ┌─────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┐ │ My Jarvis Desktop │ │ ┌───────────────────────────────────────────────────────┐ │ │ │ FilePreview Component │ │ │ │ ┌─────────────────────────────────────────────────┐ │ │ │ │ │ Sandpack Provider │ │ │ │ │ │ ┌───────────────────────────────────────────┐ │ │ │ │ │ │ │ Sandpack Bundler (WebWorker) │ │ │ │ │ │ │ │ - Transpiles JSX/TSX │ │ │ │ │ │ │ │ - Resolves npm packages │ │ │ │ │ │ │ │ - Bundles dependencies │ │ │ │ │ │ │ └───────────────────────────────────────────┘ │ │ │ │ │ │ ┌───────────────────────────────────────────┐ │ │ │ │ │ │ │ Sandpack Preview (iframe) │ │ │ │ │ │ │ │ - Isolated execution context │ │ │ │ │ │ │ │ - Renders React components │ │ │ │ │ │ │ │ - Hot reloading on changes │ │ │ │ │ │ │ └───────────────────────────────────────────┘ │ │ │ │ │ └─────────────────────────────────────────────────┘ │ │ │ └───────────────────────────────────────────────────────┘ │ └─────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┘ ``` ### Key Components 1. **SandpackProvider**: Context wrapper that manages bundler state 2. **SandpackCodeEditor**: Optional code editor component 3. **SandpackPreview**: iframe that displays rendered output 4. **Sandpack**: All-in-one component (editor + preview) 5. **useSandpack**: React hook for programmatic control --- ## Use Cases for My Jarvis Desktop ### 1. Dynamic Presentations (Primary - Daniel Use Case) **Problem**: Need to create custom presentations without pre-registering components **Solution**: ```tsx // Claude generates: presentation.tsx import { Deck, Slide, Heading, Text } from 'spectacle'; export default function Presentation() { return ( Daniel's Business Strategy Generated by Jarvis AI Market Analysis Key insights... ); } ``` **Sandpack renders this live** → Export to PDF via browser print ### 2. Code Preview & Testing **Problem**: Users want to see generated React components before using them **Solution**: Any `.tsx` file opens in FilePreview with live preview ### 3. Interactive Documentation **Problem**: Static docs are less engaging **Solution**: Embed live code examples in MDX documentation ### 4. Component Prototyping **Problem**: Rapid iteration on UI components **Solution**: Edit → See changes instantly → Export code --- ## Installation & Integration ### Step 1: Install Package ```bash npm install @codesandbox/sandpack-react ``` ### Step 2: Basic Integration ```tsx import { Sandpack } from "@codesandbox/sandpack-react"; function FilePreview({ filePath, content }) { const isTsxFile = filePath.endsWith('.tsx') || filePath.endsWith('.jsx'); if (isTsxFile) { return ( ); } // Existing FilePreview logic for other file types return ; } ``` ### Step 3: Advanced - Custom Templates ```tsx import { SandpackProvider, SandpackPreview } from "@codesandbox/sandpack-react"; function PresentationPreview({ content }) { return ( ); } ``` --- ## Comparison with Alternatives ### Sandpack vs Web Containers (StackBlitz) | Feature | Sandpack | Web Containers | |---------|----------|----------------| | **Complexity** | Low - Just React components | High - Full Node.js runtime | | **Setup Time** | ~1 day | ~1 week | | **Performance** | Fast (no Node.js overhead) | Slower (full VM) | | **npm Packages** | Yes (CDN-based) | Yes (full npm) | | **Backend Code** | No | Yes | | **Browser Support** | All modern browsers | Chrome/Edge only | | **Use Case** | Frontend preview | Full-stack apps | | **Memory Usage** | ~50-100MB | ~300-500MB | **Verdict**: Sandpack is perfect for My Jarvis Desktop's needs. ### Sandpack vs Babel + iframe | Feature | Sandpack | Babel + iframe | |---------|----------|----------------| | **Maintenance** | Production-ready library | Custom implementation | | **npm Packages** | Built-in support | Manual CDN management | | **Hot Reload** | Yes | No | | **TypeScript** | Native support | Requires additional config | | **Error Handling** | Robust | Custom implementation needed | **Verdict**: Sandpack is significantly better than rolling your own solution. --- ## Technical Capabilities ### 1. npm Package Resolution Sandpack can import packages dynamically: ```tsx import { Button } from '@mui/material'; import { useState } from 'react'; import confetti from 'canvas-confetti'; function Demo() { return ; } ``` **How it works**: Sandpack fetches packages from unpkg.com CDN and bundles them in the browser. ### 2. Multi-File Support ```tsx ``` ### 3. Custom Dependencies ```tsx ``` ### 4. Theme Customization ```tsx ``` --- ## Performance Considerations ### Memory Usage - **Initial Load**: ~30-50MB (bundler code) - **Per Preview**: ~20-40MB (depends on complexity) - **With npm packages**: +10-30MB (cached packages) **Total for 1 preview**: ~50-100MB **Acceptable for Electron app**: Yes ### Bundle Time - **Simple component**: 100-300ms - **With dependencies**: 500ms-2s (first time, then cached) - **Hot reload**: 50-200ms ### Optimization Strategies 1. Lazy load Sandpack only when needed (`.tsx` files) 2. Cache bundler worker across previews 3. Preload common packages (React, Spectacle) 4. Use SandpackPreview without editor for read-only mode --- ## Security ### Sandboxing - Runs in **iframe with sandbox attributes** - No access to parent window by default - No file system access outside virtual FS - Network requests can be controlled ### Safe for User-Generated Code - Yes, Sandpack is designed for untrusted code execution - Same security model as CodeSandbox - Used in production by many documentation sites --- ## Limitations & Considerations ### What Sandpack CAN'T Do 1. **No Node.js APIs**: Can't use `fs`, `path`, `child_process` 2. **No Backend**: Can't run Express servers or APIs 3. **Limited Package Support**: Some packages require Node.js (e.g., `sharp`) 4. **No Native Modules**: Can't use native bindings ### What Sandpack CAN Do 1. ✅ All React components 2. ✅ Most npm packages (frontend-only) 3. ✅ CSS/SCSS 4. ✅ TypeScript/JSX 5. ✅ State management (Redux, Zustand, etc.) 6. ✅ Animation libraries 7. ✅ Presentation libraries (Spectacle, Reveal.js) --- ## Production Examples ### Who Uses Sandpack? 1. **CodeSandbox Docs** - Interactive documentation 2. **React Documentation** - Live code examples 3. **Docusaurus** - Code playgrounds in docs 4. **Storybook** - Component preview (considering migration) 5. **Education platforms** - Interactive coding tutorials --- ## Implementation Plan for My Jarvis Desktop ### Phase 1: Basic Integration (Day 1) - [ ] Install `@codesandbox/sandpack-react` - [ ] Modify `FilePreview.tsx` to detect `.tsx`/`.jsx` files - [ ] Render basic Sandpack preview for React files - [ ] Test with simple component ### Phase 2: Presentation Support (Day 2) - [ ] Install Spectacle presentation library - [ ] Create presentation template generator - [ ] Add PDF export functionality (browser print) - [ ] Test with Daniel's use case ### Phase 3: Enhanced Features (Day 3-4) - [ ] Add editor mode (edit code in preview) - [ ] Implement hot reload for file changes - [ ] Add custom theme matching app design - [ ] Optimize loading performance ### Phase 4: Advanced Capabilities (Week 2) - [ ] Multi-file project support - [ ] npm package installation UI - [ ] Export project to standalone files - [ ] Error handling and debugging UI --- ## Code Examples ### Example 1: Basic FilePreview Integration ```tsx // app/components/FilePreview.tsx import { Sandpack } from "@codesandbox/sandpack-react"; export function FilePreview({ filePath, content }: FilePreviewProps) { const isReactFile = /\.(tsx|jsx)$/.test(filePath); const isMarkdown = /\.(md|mdx)$/.test(filePath); if (isReactFile) { return (
); } if (isMarkdown) { return ; } return ; } ``` ### Example 2: Presentation Preview ```tsx // app/components/PresentationPreview.tsx import { SandpackProvider, SandpackPreview, SandpackLayout } from "@codesandbox/sandpack-react"; interface PresentationPreviewProps { slides: string; // TSX content } export function PresentationPreview({ slides }: PresentationPreviewProps) { const files = { "/App.tsx": slides, "/package.json": JSON.stringify({ dependencies: { "spectacle": "^10.0.0", "react": "^18.2.0", "react-dom": "^18.2.0" } }) }; return (
); } ``` ### Example 3: Claude-Generated Presentation ```tsx // Example output from Claude when asked to create presentation import { Deck, Slide, Heading, Text, UnorderedList, ListItem } from 'spectacle'; export default function DanielPresentation() { return ( Business Strategy 2025 Prepared for Daniel Market Analysis Target market: $50M TAM Growth rate: 15% YoY Competition: 3 major players Recommendations Focus on differentiation through... ); } ``` --- ## Export to PDF Strategy ### Browser Print API ```tsx function exportToPDF() { // CSS for print layout const style = document.createElement('style'); style.textContent = ` @media print { @page { size: landscape; margin: 0; } .no-print { display: none; } } `; document.head.appendChild(style); // Trigger print dialog window.print(); // Cleanup document.head.removeChild(style); } ``` ### Alternative: PDF Generation Library ```tsx import html2canvas from 'html2canvas'; import jsPDF from 'jspdf'; async function exportToPDF(element: HTMLElement) { const canvas = await html2canvas(element); const imgData = canvas.toDataURL('image/png'); const pdf = new jsPDF('landscape', 'mm', 'a4'); const imgWidth = 297; const imgHeight = (canvas.height * imgWidth) / canvas.width; pdf.addImage(imgData, 'PNG', 0, 0, imgWidth, imgHeight); pdf.save('presentation.pdf'); } ``` --- ## Next Steps ### Immediate Actions 1. **Install Sandpack**: `npm install @codesandbox/sandpack-react` 2. **Create POC**: Test basic `.tsx` file rendering 3. **Test with Spectacle**: Verify presentation use case works 4. **Validate performance**: Measure memory and bundle time ### For Daniel Meeting Tomorrow 1. Create simple presentation template 2. Test end-to-end: Generate → Preview → Export PDF 3. Prepare demo showing live editing 4. Document workflow for Daniel's team ### Long-term Integration 1. Integrate into FilePreview component 2. Add UI controls (theme, layout, export) 3. Create presentation template library 4. Build AI prompt templates for common presentation types --- ## Risk Assessment ### Low Risk ✅ - Sandpack is production-ready (used by CodeSandbox, React docs) - Active maintenance and community support - Well-documented API - Predictable performance characteristics ### Medium Risk ⚠️ - npm package compatibility (some packages may fail) - Memory usage with multiple previews - Electron integration quirks (if any) ### Mitigation - Test with common packages early - Implement lazy loading - Add fallback to code view if preview fails - Monitor memory usage in production --- ## Conclusion **Sandpack is the optimal solution for dynamic React preview in My Jarvis Desktop.** **Pros**: - ✅ Production-ready and battle-tested - ✅ Perfect fit for presentation use case - ✅ Quick implementation (~1 day basic, 3-4 days complete) - ✅ No custom bundler maintenance - ✅ Excellent performance for Electron app - ✅ Future-proof (active development) **Cons**: - ⚠️ Some npm packages won't work (Node.js-only) - ⚠️ Memory overhead (acceptable for desktop app) - ⚠️ CDN dependency for packages (could be mitigated with caching) **Recommendation**: Proceed with Sandpack integration. # Sandpack Research Findings - Dynamic React Preview System **Ticket**: #066 **Created**: 2025-10-20 **Context**: Enable dynamic React component rendering for presentations (Daniel use case) and general code preview --- ## Executive Summary Sandpack is CodeSandbox's open-source browser-based bundler that enables live React component preview without pre-registration. It's the ideal solution for creating dynamic presentations and previewing generated code within My Jarvis Desktop. **Key Recommendation**: Integrate Sandpack into FilePreview component to render `.tsx`/`.jsx` files as live, interactive components. --- ## What is Sandpack? ### Overview - **Maintained by**: CodeSandbox team - **Type**: Browser-based bundler and code execution environment - **Primary Use**: Live code preview, interactive documentation, code playgrounds - **License**: Open source - **Package**: `@codesandbox/sandpack-react` ### Core Capabilities 1. **In-Browser Bundling**: Compiles JSX/TSX to JavaScript in the browser 2. **npm Package Support**: Can import and use npm packages dynamically 3. **Hot Module Reloading**: Real-time updates without full page refresh 4. **Sandboxed Execution**: Runs code in isolated iframe for security 5. **Multiple Templates**: React, Vue, Vanilla JS, Angular support 6. **File System API**: Virtual file system for multi-file projects 7. **TypeScript Support**: Native TSX/JSX compilation --- ## Architecture ### How Sandpack Works ``` ┌─────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┐ │ My Jarvis Desktop │ │ ┌───────────────────────────────────────────────────────┐ │ │ │ FilePreview Component │ │ │ │ ┌─────────────────────────────────────────────────┐ │ │ │ │ │ Sandpack Provider │ │ │ │ │ │ ┌───────────────────────────────────────────┐ │ │ │ │ │ │ │ Sandpack Bundler (WebWorker) │ │ │ │ │ │ │ │ - Transpiles JSX/TSX │ │ │ │ │ │ │ │ - Resolves npm packages │ │ │ │ │ │ │ │ - Bundles dependencies │ │ │ │ │ │ │ └───────────────────────────────────────────┘ │ │ │ │ │ │ ┌───────────────────────────────────────────┐ │ │ │ │ │ │ │ Sandpack Preview (iframe) │ │ │ │ │ │ │ │ - Isolated execution context │ │ │ │ │ │ │ │ - Renders React components │ │ │ │ │ │ │ │ - Hot reloading on changes │ │ │ │ │ │ │ └───────────────────────────────────────────┘ │ │ │ │ │ └─────────────────────────────────────────────────┘ │ │ │ └───────────────────────────────────────────────────────┘ │ └─────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┘ ``` ### Key Components 1. **SandpackProvider**: Context wrapper that manages bundler state 2. **SandpackCodeEditor**: Optional code editor component 3. **SandpackPreview**: iframe that displays rendered output 4. **Sandpack**: All-in-one component (editor + preview) 5. **useSandpack**: React hook for programmatic control --- ## Use Cases for My Jarvis Desktop ### 1. Dynamic Presentations (Primary - Daniel Use Case) **Problem**: Need to create custom presentations without pre-registering components **Solution**: ```tsx // Claude generates: presentation.tsx import { Deck, Slide, Heading, Text } from 'spectacle'; export default function Presentation() { return ( Daniel's Business Strategy Generated by Jarvis AI Market Analysis Key insights... ); } ``` **Sandpack renders this live** → Export to PDF via browser print ### 2. Code Preview & Testing **Problem**: Users want to see generated React components before using them **Solution**: Any `.tsx` file opens in FilePreview with live preview ### 3. Interactive Documentation **Problem**: Static docs are less engaging **Solution**: Embed live code examples in MDX documentation ### 4. Component Prototyping **Problem**: Rapid iteration on UI components **Solution**: Edit → See changes instantly → Export code --- ## Installation & Integration ### Step 1: Install Package ```bash npm install @codesandbox/sandpack-react ``` ### Step 2: Basic Integration ```tsx import { Sandpack } from "@codesandbox/sandpack-react"; function FilePreview({ filePath, content }) { const isTsxFile = filePath.endsWith('.tsx') || filePath.endsWith('.jsx'); if (isTsxFile) { return ( ); } // Existing FilePreview logic for other file types return ; } ``` ### Step 3: Advanced - Custom Templates ```tsx import { SandpackProvider, SandpackPreview } from "@codesandbox/sandpack-react"; function PresentationPreview({ content }) { return ( ); } ``` --- ## Comparison with Alternatives ### Sandpack vs Web Containers (StackBlitz) | Feature | Sandpack | Web Containers | |---------|----------|----------------| | **Complexity** | Low - Just React components | High - Full Node.js runtime | | **Setup Time** | ~1 day | ~1 week | | **Performance** | Fast (no Node.js overhead) | Slower (full VM) | | **npm Packages** | Yes (CDN-based) | Yes (full npm) | | **Backend Code** | No | Yes | | **Browser Support** | All modern browsers | Chrome/Edge only | | **Use Case** | Frontend preview | Full-stack apps | | **Memory Usage** | ~50-100MB | ~300-500MB | **Verdict**: Sandpack is perfect for My Jarvis Desktop's needs. ### Sandpack vs Babel + iframe | Feature | Sandpack | Babel + iframe | |---------|----------|----------------| | **Maintenance** | Production-ready library | Custom implementation | | **npm Packages** | Built-in support | Manual CDN management | | **Hot Reload** | Yes | No | | **TypeScript** | Native support | Requires additional config | | **Error Handling** | Robust | Custom implementation needed | **Verdict**: Sandpack is significantly better than rolling your own solution. --- ## Technical Capabilities ### 1. npm Package Resolution Sandpack can import packages dynamically: ```tsx import { Button } from '@mui/material'; import { useState } from 'react'; import confetti from 'canvas-confetti'; function Demo() { return ; } ``` **How it works**: Sandpack fetches packages from unpkg.com CDN and bundles them in the browser. ### 2. Multi-File Support ```tsx ``` ### 3. Custom Dependencies ```tsx ``` ### 4. Theme Customization ```tsx ``` --- ## Performance Considerations ### Memory Usage - **Initial Load**: ~30-50MB (bundler code) - **Per Preview**: ~20-40MB (depends on complexity) - **With npm packages**: +10-30MB (cached packages) **Total for 1 preview**: ~50-100MB **Acceptable for Electron app**: Yes ### Bundle Time - **Simple component**: 100-300ms - **With dependencies**: 500ms-2s (first time, then cached) - **Hot reload**: 50-200ms ### Optimization Strategies 1. Lazy load Sandpack only when needed (`.tsx` files) 2. Cache bundler worker across previews 3. Preload common packages (React, Spectacle) 4. Use SandpackPreview without editor for read-only mode --- ## Security ### Sandboxing - Runs in **iframe with sandbox attributes** - No access to parent window by default - No file system access outside virtual FS - Network requests can be controlled ### Safe for User-Generated Code - Yes, Sandpack is designed for untrusted code execution - Same security model as CodeSandbox - Used in production by many documentation sites --- ## Limitations & Considerations ### What Sandpack CAN'T Do 1. **No Node.js APIs**: Can't use `fs`, `path`, `child_process` 2. **No Backend**: Can't run Express servers or APIs 3. **Limited Package Support**: Some packages require Node.js (e.g., `sharp`) 4. **No Native Modules**: Can't use native bindings ### What Sandpack CAN Do 1. ✅ All React components 2. ✅ Most npm packages (frontend-only) 3. ✅ CSS/SCSS 4. ✅ TypeScript/JSX 5. ✅ State management (Redux, Zustand, etc.) 6. ✅ Animation libraries 7. ✅ Presentation libraries (Spectacle, Reveal.js) --- ## Production Examples ### Who Uses Sandpack? 1. **CodeSandbox Docs** - Interactive documentation 2. **React Documentation** - Live code examples 3. **Docusaurus** - Code playgrounds in docs 4. **Storybook** - Component preview (considering migration) 5. **Education platforms** - Interactive coding tutorials --- ## Implementation Plan for My Jarvis Desktop ### Phase 1: Basic Integration (Day 1) - [ ] Install `@codesandbox/sandpack-react` - [ ] Modify `FilePreview.tsx` to detect `.tsx`/`.jsx` files - [ ] Render basic Sandpack preview for React files - [ ] Test with simple component ### Phase 2: Presentation Support (Day 2) - [ ] Install Spectacle presentation library - [ ] Create presentation template generator - [ ] Add PDF export functionality (browser print) - [ ] Test with Daniel's use case ### Phase 3: Enhanced Features (Day 3-4) - [ ] Add editor mode (edit code in preview) - [ ] Implement hot reload for file changes - [ ] Add custom theme matching app design - [ ] Optimize loading performance ### Phase 4: Advanced Capabilities (Week 2) - [ ] Multi-file project support - [ ] npm package installation UI - [ ] Export project to standalone files - [ ] Error handling and debugging UI --- ## Code Examples ### Example 1: Basic FilePreview Integration ```tsx // app/components/FilePreview.tsx import { Sandpack } from "@codesandbox/sandpack-react"; export function FilePreview({ filePath, content }: FilePreviewProps) { const isReactFile = /\.(tsx|jsx)$/.test(filePath); const isMarkdown = /\.(md|mdx)$/.test(filePath); if (isReactFile) { return (
); } if (isMarkdown) { return ; } return ; } ``` ### Example 2: Presentation Preview ```tsx // app/components/PresentationPreview.tsx import { SandpackProvider, SandpackPreview, SandpackLayout } from "@codesandbox/sandpack-react"; interface PresentationPreviewProps { slides: string; // TSX content } export function PresentationPreview({ slides }: PresentationPreviewProps) { const files = { "/App.tsx": slides, "/package.json": JSON.stringify({ dependencies: { "spectacle": "^10.0.0", "react": "^18.2.0", "react-dom": "^18.2.0" } }) }; return (
); } ``` ### Example 3: Claude-Generated Presentation ```tsx // Example output from Claude when asked to create presentation import { Deck, Slide, Heading, Text, UnorderedList, ListItem } from 'spectacle'; export default function DanielPresentation() { return ( Business Strategy 2025 Prepared for Daniel Market Analysis Target market: $50M TAM Growth rate: 15% YoY Competition: 3 major players Recommendations Focus on differentiation through... ); } ``` --- ## Export to PDF Strategy ### Browser Print API ```tsx function exportToPDF() { // CSS for print layout const style = document.createElement('style'); style.textContent = ` @media print { @page { size: landscape; margin: 0; } .no-print { display: none; } } `; document.head.appendChild(style); // Trigger print dialog window.print(); // Cleanup document.head.removeChild(style); } ``` ### Alternative: PDF Generation Library ```tsx import html2canvas from 'html2canvas'; import jsPDF from 'jspdf'; async function exportToPDF(element: HTMLElement) { const canvas = await html2canvas(element); const imgData = canvas.toDataURL('image/png'); const pdf = new jsPDF('landscape', 'mm', 'a4'); const imgWidth = 297; const imgHeight = (canvas.height * imgWidth) / canvas.width; pdf.addImage(imgData, 'PNG', 0, 0, imgWidth, imgHeight); pdf.save('presentation.pdf'); } ``` --- ## Next Steps ### Immediate Actions 1. **Install Sandpack**: `npm install @codesandbox/sandpack-react` 2. **Create POC**: Test basic `.tsx` file rendering 3. **Test with Spectacle**: Verify presentation use case works 4. **Validate performance**: Measure memory and bundle time ### For Daniel Meeting Tomorrow 1. Integrate into FilePreview component 2. Add UI controls (theme, layout, export) 3. Create presentation template library 4. Build AI prompt templates for common presentation types --- ## Risk Assessment ### Low Risk ✅ - Sandpack is production-ready (used by CodeSandbox, React docs) - Active maintenance and community support - Well-documented API - Predictable performance characteristics ### Medium Risk ⚠️ - npm package compatibility (some packages may fail) - Memory usage with multiple previews - Electron integration quirks (if any) ### Mitigation - Test with common packages early - Implement lazy loading - Add fallback to code view if preview fails - Monitor memory usage in production --- ## Conclusion **Sandpack is the optimal solution for dynamic React preview in My Jarvis Desktop.** **Pros**: - ✅ Production-ready and battle-tested - ✅ Perfect fit for presentation use case - ✅ Quick implementation (~1 day basic, 3-4 days complete) - ✅ No custom bundler maintenance - ✅ Excellent performance for Electron app - ✅ Future-proof (active development) **Cons**: - ⚠️ Some npm packages won't work (Node.js-only) - ⚠️ Memory overhead (acceptable for desktop app) - ⚠️ CDN dependency for packages (could be mitigated with caching) **Recommendation**: Proceed with Sandpack integration. It's the ideal solution for creating dynamic presentations and previewing generated code within My Jarvis Desktop. **Key Recommendation**: Integrate Sandpack into FilePreview component to render `.tsx`/`.jsx` files as live, interactive components. --- ## What is Sandpack? ### Overview - **Maintained by**: CodeSandbox team - **Type**: Browser-based bundler and code execution environment - **Primary Use**: Live code preview, interactive documentation, code playgrounds - **License**: Open source - **Package**: `@codesandbox/sandpack-react` ### Core Capabilities 1. **In-Browser Bundling**: Compiles JSX/TSX to JavaScript in the browser 2. **npm Package Support**: Can import and use npm packages dynamically 3. **Hot Module Reloading**: Real-time updates without full page refresh 4. **Sandboxed Execution**: Runs code in isolated iframe for security 5. **Multiple Templates**: React, Vue, Vanilla JS, Angular support 6. **File System API**: Virtual file system for multi-file projects 7. **TypeScript Support**: Native TSX/JSX compilation --- ## Architecture ### How Sandpack Works ``` ┌─────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┐ │ My Jarvis Desktop │ │ ┌───────────────────────────────────────────────────────┐ │ │ │ FilePreview Component │ │ │ │ ┌─────────────────────────────────────────────────┐ │ │ │ │ │ Sandpack Provider │ │ │ │ │ │ ┌───────────────────────────────────────────┐ │ │ │ │ │ │ │ Sandpack Bundler (WebWorker) │ │ │ │ │ │ │ │ - Transpiles JSX/TSX │ │ │ │ │ │ │ │ - Resolves npm packages │ │ │ │ │ │ │ │ - Bundles dependencies │ │ │ │ │ │ │ └───────────────────────────────────────────┘ │ │ │ │ │ │ ┌───────────────────────────────────────────┐ │ │ │ │ │ │ │ Sandpack Preview (iframe) │ │ │ │ │ │ │ │ - Isolated execution context │ │ │ │ │ │ │ │ - Renders React components │ │ │ │ │ │ │ │ - Hot reloading on changes │ │ │ │ │ │ │ └───────────────────────────────────────────┘ │ │ │ │ │ └─────────────────────────────────────────────────┘ │ │ │ └───────────────────────────────────────────────────────┘ │ └─────────────────────────────────────────────────────────────┘ ``` ### Key Components 1. **SandpackProvider**: Context wrapper that manages bundler state 2. **SandpackCodeEditor**: Optional code editor component 3. **SandpackPreview**: iframe that displays rendered output 4. **Sandpack**: All-in-one component (editor + preview) 5. **useSandpack**: React hook for programmatic control --- ## Use Cases for My Jarvis Desktop ### 1. Dynamic Presentations (Primary - Daniel Use Case) **Problem**: Need to create custom presentations without pre-registering components **Solution**: ```tsx // Claude generates: presentation.tsx import { Deck, Slide, Heading, Text } from 'spectacle'; export default function Presentation() { return ( Daniel's Business Strategy Generated by Jarvis AI Market Analysis Key insights... ); } ``` **Sandpack renders this live** → Export to PDF via browser print ### 2. Code Preview & Testing **Problem**: Users want to see generated React components before using them **Solution**: Any `.tsx` file opens in FilePreview with live preview ### 3. Interactive Documentation **Problem**: Static docs are less engaging **Solution**: Embed live code examples in MDX documentation ### 4. Component Prototyping **Problem**: Rapid iteration on UI components **Solution**: Edit → See changes instantly → Export code --- ## Installation & Integration ### Step 1: Install Package ```bash npm install @codesandbox/sandpack-react ``` ### Step 2: Basic Integration ```tsx import { Sandpack } from "@codesandbox/sandpack-react"; function FilePreview({ filePath, content }) { const isTsxFile = filePath.endsWith('.tsx') || filePath.endsWith('.jsx'); if (isTsxFile) { return ( ); } // Existing FilePreview logic for other file types return ; } ``` ### Step 3: Advanced - Custom Templates ```tsx import { SandpackProvider, SandpackPreview } from "@codesandbox/sandpack-react"; function PresentationPreview({ content }) { return ( ); } ``` --- ## Comparison with Alternatives ### Sandpack vs Web Containers (StackBlitz) | Feature | Sandpack | Web Containers | |---------|----------|----------------| | **Complexity** | Low - Just React components | High - Full Node.js runtime | | **Setup Time** | ~1 day | ~1 week | | **Performance** | Fast (no Node.js overhead) | Slower (full VM) | | **npm Packages** | Yes (CDN-based) | Yes (full npm) | | **Backend Code** | No | Yes | | **Browser Support** | All modern browsers | Chrome/Edge only | | **Use Case** | Frontend preview | Full-stack apps | | **Memory Usage** | ~50-100MB | ~300-500MB | **Verdict**: Sandpack is perfect for My Jarvis Desktop's needs. ### Sandpack vs Babel + iframe | Feature | Sandpack | Babel + iframe | |---------|----------|----------------| | **Maintenance** | Production-ready library | Custom implementation | | **npm Packages** | Built-in support | Manual CDN management | | **Hot Reload** | Yes | No | | **TypeScript** | Native support | Requires additional config | | **Error Handling** | Robust | Custom implementation needed | **Verdict**: Sandpack is significantly better than rolling your own solution. --- ## Technical Capabilities ### 1. npm Package Resolution Sandpack can import packages dynamically: ```tsx import { Button } from '@mui/material'; import { useState } from 'react'; import confetti from 'canvas-confetti'; function Demo() { return ; } ``` **How it works**: Sandpack fetches packages from unpkg.com CDN and bundles them in the browser. ### 2. Multi-File Support ```tsx ``` ### 3. Custom Dependencies ```tsx ``` ### 4. Theme Customization ```tsx ``` --- ## Performance Considerations ### Memory Usage - **Initial Load**: ~30-50MB (bundler code) - **Per Preview**: ~20-40MB (depends on complexity) - **With npm packages**: +10-30MB (cached packages) **Total for 1 preview**: ~50-100MB **Acceptable for Electron app**: Yes ### Bundle Time - **Simple component**: 100-300ms - **With dependencies**: 500ms-2s (first time, then cached) - **Hot reload**: 50-200ms ### Optimization Strategies 1. Lazy load Sandpack only when needed (`.tsx` files) 2. Cache bundler worker across previews 3. Preload common packages (React, Spectacle) 4. Use SandpackPreview without editor for read-only mode --- ## Security ### Sandboxing - Runs in **iframe with sandbox attributes** - No access to parent window by default - No file system access outside virtual FS - Network requests can be controlled ### Safe for User-Generated Code - Yes, Sandpack is designed for untrusted code execution - Same security model as CodeSandbox - Used in production by many documentation sites --- ## Limitations & Considerations ### What Sandpack CAN'T Do 1. **No Node.js APIs**: Can't use `fs`, `path`, `child_process` 2. **No Backend**: Can't run Express servers or APIs 3. **Limited Package Support**: Some packages require Node.js (e.g., `sharp`) 4. **No Native Modules**: Can't use native bindings ### What Sandpack CAN Do 1. ✅ All React components 2. ✅ Most npm packages (frontend-only) 3. ✅ CSS/SCSS 4. ✅ TypeScript/JSX 5. ✅ State management (Redux, Zustand, etc.) 6. ✅ Animation libraries 7. ✅ Presentation libraries (Spectacle, Reveal.js) --- ## Production Examples ### Who Uses Sandpack? message.content: Okay, now I want you to explain to me how this Sandpack works. What's the advantage of us using it? Why do you think it's the best option? How does it work? Explain in detail with one long voice message, only one voice message.

input.command: ./tools/src/jarvis_voice.sh --voice echo "Alright, let me explain Sandpack in depth. Sandpack is CodeSandbox's open-source bundler that runs entirely in the browser. Here's how it works: when you give it JSX or TSX code, it spins up a Web Worker that acts as a bundler, transpiles your code using Babel, resolves npm package imports by fetching them from unpkg CDN, bundles everything together, and then renders the result in a sandboxed iframe. The magic is that all of this happens client-side, no server needed. Now, why is this the best option for you? Three main reasons. First, it solves your core problem with MDX. Right now, your MDX components must be pre-registered in the app. You can't create new React components on the fly because they need to be compiled into the application bundle ahead of time. With Sandpack, Claude can generate a fresh TSX file for Daniel's presentation, and Sandpack will compile and render it instantly without any pre-registration. It's true dynamic React rendering. Second, it's production-ready and battle-tested. This isn't some experimental library. CodeSandbox uses it in production, the official React documentation uses it for their live code examples, Docusaurus uses it, education platforms use it. It's maintained by a strong team, has excellent documentation, and handles edge cases you'd spend weeks debugging if you built this yourself. Third, it's the right level of complexity for your use case. You looked at alternatives like StackBlitz Web Containers, which run a full Node.js runtime in the browser using WebAssembly. That's overkill. You don't need a backend, you don't need file system APIs, you just need to render React components. Sandpack is lighter, faster, and simpler. It uses 50 to 100 megabytes of memory versus 300 to 500 for Web Containers. Bundle time is 100 to 300 milliseconds for simple components. That's instant feedback. Now let's talk about the presentation workflow for Daniel. Claude asks Daniel about his business, his goals, his audience. Claude then generates a TSX file using Spectacle, which is a React-based presentation library. The file exports a Deck component with Slide components inside. Sandpack receives this TSX file, bundles it with Spectacle from the CDN, renders it live in your FilePreview component, and Daniel sees a beautiful presentation instantly. He can ask Claude to modify it, add slides, change content, adjust styling, whatever. Each change re-renders in 50 to 200 milliseconds thanks to hot module reloading. When he's happy, you trigger the browser print API or use a library like jsPDF to export it as a PDF. Done. Presentation created, customized, and exported without ever leaving My Jarvis Desktop. The technical architecture is elegant. You install the Sandpack React package, import the Sandpack component, pass it a files object with your TSX content, specify the React TypeScript template, and it handles everything. You can customize the theme to match your dark UI, hide the code editor and show only the preview, disable the open in CodeSandbox button, and control every aspect of the experience. For your FilePreview component, you add a simple check: if the file ends in TSX or JSX, render it with Sandpack instead of your existing preview logic. That's it. One conditional, one component, and you have dynamic React rendering. The security is solid too. Sandpack runs code in an iframe with sandbox attributes, so it can't access your parent window, can't touch the file system outside its virtual environment, and network requests are controlled. It's designed for running untrusted code, which is exactly what you need when Claude is generating code dynamically. Now, the limitations. Sandpack can't run Node.js APIs like fs or child process. It can't run backend servers. Some npm packages that depend on native modules won't work. But for your use case, presentations and frontend components, these limitations don't matter. You're not building Express apps in Sandpack, you're rendering React slides. The implementation timeline is fast. Day one, install Sandpack and modify FilePreview to detect TSX files and render them. Day two, add Spectacle and create a presentation template generator. Day three and four, add editor mode if you want users to edit code directly, implement hot reload for file changes, and optimize performance with lazy loading. By the end of the week, you have a fully functional dynamic presentation system ready for Daniel's meeting. The confidence level on this recommendation is nine out of ten. The only uncertainty is minor Electron integration quirks, but Sandpack is just React components and Web Workers, so there's no reason it wouldn't work perfectly in Electron. The risk is low, the upside is huge, and the implementation is straightforward. This is the right move."
input.description: Detailed explanation of Sandpack architecture and advantages

input.command: ./tools/src/jarvis_voice.sh --voice echo "Let me explain Sandpack comprehensively. Sandpack is CodeSandbox's browser-based bundler that solves your core MDX problem. Currently, your MDX components must be pre-registered - you can't create new React components dynamically because they need compilation ahead of time. Sandpack changes everything. It runs entirely client-side using a Web Worker that transpiles JSX via Babel, fetches npm packages from unpkg CDN, bundles everything, and renders in a sandboxed iframe. No server needed. Why is this best? Three reasons. First, true dynamic rendering. Claude generates a TSX file for Daniel's presentation using Spectacle library, Sandpack compiles it instantly without pre-registration, renders it live in FilePreview, and Daniel sees his presentation immediately. Second, production-ready. CodeSandbox, React docs, and Docusaurus all use it. Battle-tested with excellent documentation. Third, right complexity level. Web Containers run full Node.js which is overkill. You just need React rendering. Sandpack uses 50-100MB versus 300-500MB, bundles in 100-300ms, and re-renders in 50-200ms with hot reload. The workflow is elegant: Claude interviews Daniel, generates Spectacle TSX, Sandpack renders it, Daniel iterates with Claude making changes instantly, then exports to PDF via browser print. Implementation is simple - one conditional in FilePreview checking for TSX extension, render with Sandpack component, done. Security is solid with iframe sandboxing. Limitations don't matter for your use case - no Node APIs or backends needed for presentations. Timeline: Day one integrate Sandpack, day two add Spectacle and PDF export, days three-four optimize. Confidence nine out of ten. This is the right move."

message.content:
Okay, so let's just now think about this step-by-step.
1. I wanna understand, let's say we wanna just create, we integrated this sandbox thing. We now have it as part of our file preview. That's a question. Now it's like another mode of our file preview work.
2. If we see a TSX file, then we just show it as a React component.
3. Now let's imagine that we have a presentation with 5 slides, and I can click inside the React component to just change slides. So it's really just like one React component that I can click and change things.
4. Is it actually like interactive React components that it's created?
5. Let's say now we created 5 slides. Now I wanna actually create a PDF out of it or a PowerPoint, probably a PDF. How do we approach that? Is there a way? We need to actually create like a PDF out of it. So how does that work?
Can you answer everything in one voice message?

input.command: ./tools/src/jarvis_voice.sh --voice echo "Yes, let me walk through this step by step. First, Sandpack integration into FilePreview - exactly right. You add a condition that checks if the file ends in TSX or JSX, and if so, you render the Sandpack component instead of your current preview logic. It becomes another preview mode alongside your MDX and PDF viewers. Second, yes, TSX files render as full React components. Third, and this is key - yes, they are fully interactive. When Spectacle renders your 5-slide presentation, you can click arrow keys or on-screen buttons to navigate between slides. It's a real React app running in the iframe, not a static render. All React state, click handlers, animations, everything works exactly like a normal React app. Fourth, creating a PDF. There are two approaches. Simple approach - browser print API. You add a button that triggers window.print, which opens the browser's print dialog, and the user can save as PDF. You can inject CSS with media print queries to control page breaks and ensure each slide prints on one page in landscape mode. More robust approach - use a library like Puppeteer or Playwright on the backend. You send the Sandpack preview URL to a headless browser, it navigates through each slide, takes screenshots, and combines them into a PDF using something like PDFKit or jsPDF. This gives you pixel-perfect control. For Electron, you can use Electron's built-in printToPDF method which captures the iframe content directly. The cleanest workflow - user reviews presentation in Sandpack preview, clicks export button, Electron captures each slide programmatically by navigating the iframe through all slides, generates PDF with one slide per page, saves to disk. Done. The presentation stays fully interactive during preview, and PDF export is a separate final step."

content.content:
html2canvas is a JavaScript library that allows developers to capture screenshots of web page elements or entire viewports. Key features include:

Installation options:
- NPM: `npm install --save html2canvas`
- Yarn: `yarn add html2canvas`

Basic usage example:
```javascript
html2canvas(document.querySelector("#capture")).then(canvas => {
    document.body.appendChild(canvas)
});
```

Key capabilities:
- Render DOM elements as canvas images
- Capture specific page elements or full viewport
- Lightweight (45kb gzipped)
- MIT licensed

The library was created by Niklas von Hertzen and provides an easy way to generate screenshots directly in the browser using JavaScript.

{
  "name": "my-jarvis-desktop",
  "version": "1.30.1",
  "description": "My Jarvis Desktop - Production Electron app with claude-code-webui integration",
  "main": "./out/main/main.js",
  "license": "MIT",
  "author": {
    "name": "Erez",
    "url": "https://github.com/erezfern"
  },
  "scripts": {
    "dev": "npm run vite:build:app && cross-env NODE_ENV=development ELECTRON_DISABLE_SANDBOX=1 JARVIS_DEV_PORT=8082 VITE_JARVIS_DEV_PORT=8082 electron out/main/main.js",
    "format": "prettier --write .",
    "lint": "eslint . --ext .ts,.tsx --fix",
    "start": "electron-vite preview",
    "postinstall": "electron-builder install-app-deps",
    "prebuild": "cd lib/claude-webui-server && npm install && npm run build",
    "vite:build:app": "electron-vite build",
    "build:web": "cross-env NODE_ENV=production VITE_API_URL='' electron-vite build",
    "electron:build:win": "electron-builder --win",
    "electron:build:mac": "electron-builder --mac",
    "electron:build:linux": "electron-builder --linux",
    "electron:build:dir": "electron-builder --dir",
    "build:unpack": "run-s vite:build:app electron:build:dir",
    "build:win": "run-s vite:build:app electron:build:win",
    "build:mac": "run-s vite:build:app electron:build:mac",
    "build:linux": "run-s vite:build:app electron:build:linux",
    "test:production": "./scripts/test-production.sh",
    "verify:safe-push": "npm run test:production && echo '✅ Safe to push to remote'"
  },
  "dependencies": {
    "@anthropic-ai/claude-code": "1.0.108",
    "@electron-toolkit/preload": "^3.0.2",
    "@electron-toolkit/utils": "^4.0.0",
    "@heroicons/react": "^2.2.0",
    "@logtape/logtape": "^1.1.1",
    "@logtape/pretty": "^1.1.1",
    "@radix-ui/react-slider": "^1.3.6",
    "@react-pdf-viewer/core": "^3.12.0",
    "@react-pdf-viewer/default-layout": "^3.12.0",
    "@tanstack/react-virtual": "^3.13.12",
    "@types/express": "^5.0.3",
    "@types/markdown-it": "^14.1.2",
    "@xterm/addon-fit": "^0.10.0",
    "@xterm/addon-web-links": "^0.11.0",
    "@xterm/xterm": "^5.5.0",
    "dayjs": "^1.11.13",
    "express": "^5.1.0",
    "framer-motion": "^12.23.22",
    "lucide-react": "^0.544.0",
    "markdown-it": "^14.1.0",
    "next-mdx-remote": "^5.0.0",
    "node-pty": "^1.0.0",
    "react": "^19.1.0",
    "react-dom": "^19.1.1",
    "react-resizable-panels": "^3.0.6",
    "react-router-dom": "^7.6.2",
    "rehype-highlight": "^7.0.2",
    "remark-gfm": "^4.0.1",
    "tsx": "^4.20.6",
    "ws": "^8.18.3",
    "zod": "^4.1.3"
  },
  "devDependencies": {
    "@electron-toolkit/eslint-config-prettier": "^3.0.0",
    "@electron-toolkit/tsconfig": "^1.0.1",
    "@eslint/js": "^9.34.0",
    "@rushstack/eslint-patch": "^1.12.0",
    "@tailwindcss/postcss": "^4.1.14",
    "@tailwindcss/vite": "^4.1.13",
    "@types/node": "^24.6.1",
    "@types/react": "^19.1.12",
    "@types/react-dom": "^19.1.9",
    "@types/ws": "^8.18.1",
    "@vitejs/plugin-react-swc": "^4.1.0",
    "cross-env": "^10.0.0",
    "electron": "^37.3.1",
    "electron-builder": "^26.0.12",
    "electron-rebuild": "^3.2.9",
    "electron-vite": "^4.0.0",
    "eslint": "^9.34.0",
    "eslint-plugin-react": "^7.37.5",
    "eslint-plugin-react-hooks": "^5.2.0",
    "eslint-plugin-react-refresh": "^0.4.19",
    "globals": "^16.0.0",
    "npm-run-all": "^4.1.5",
    "prettier": "^3.6.2",
    "tailwindcss": "^4.1.12",
    "typescript": "~5.8.3",
    "typescript-eslint": "^8.42.0",
    "vite": "^7.1.6"
  }
}

1→import { BrowserWindow, shell } from 'electron'
     2→import { join } from 'path'
     3→import { registerFileHandlers } from '../conveyor/handlers/file-handler'
     4→
     5→export async function createAppWindow(): Promise<BrowserWindow> {
     6→  // Create the browser window.
     7→  const mainWindow = new BrowserWindow({
     8→    width: 1200,
     9→    height: 800,
    10→    show: false,
    11→    autoHideMenuBar: true,
    12→    center: true,
    13→    minimizable: true,
    14→    maximizable: true,
    15→    webPreferences: {
    16→      preload: join(__dirname, '../preload/preload.js'),
    17→      sandbox: false,
    18→      nodeIntegration: false,
    19→      contextIsolation: true,
    20→      webSecurity: false  // Allow local file access for audio files
    21→    }
    22→  })
    23→
    24→  mainWindow.on('ready-to-show', () => {
    25→    console.log('Window ready to show, attempting to display...')
    26→    try {
    27→      mainWindow.show()
    28→      mainWindow.focus()
    29→      mainWindow.setAlwaysOnTop(true)
    30→      mainWindow.setAlwaysOnTop(false) // Just to bring to front
    31→      console.log('Window should now be visible')
    32→    } catch (error) {
    33→      console.error('Error showing window:', error)
    34→    }
    35→  })
    36→
    37→  mainWindow.webContents.on('did-fail-load', (event, errorCode, errorDescription) => {
    38→    console.error('Window failed to load:', errorCode, errorDescription)
    39→  })
    40→
    41→  mainWindow.webContents.on('crashed', () => {
    42→    console.error('Window crashed!')
    43→  })
    44→
    45→  mainWindow.webContents.setWindowOpenHandler((details) => {
    46→    shell.openExternal(details.url)
    47→    return { action: 'deny' }
    48→  })
    49→
    50→  // Register file system handlers
    51→  registerFileHandlers(mainWindow)
    52→
    53→  // Load the Claude WebUI server
    54→  // For both development and production, load from the Claude WebUI server
    55→  const devPort = process.env.JARVIS_DEV_PORT || '8081'
    56→  if (process.env.NODE_ENV === 'development') {
    57→    // In development, use the JARVIS_DEV_PORT (8082 by default in dev script)
    58→    mainWindow.loadURL(`http://127.0.0.1:${devPort}`)
    59→    mainWindow.webContents.openDevTools()
    60→  } else {
    61→    // In production, load from the Claude WebUI server static files
    62→    mainWindow.loadURL('http://127.0.0.1:8081')
    63→  }
    64→
    65→  return mainWindow
    66→}

This changes everything for PDF generation. Electron's printToPDF won't work because there's no Electron main process. Here's the web-based solution. For the conversational PDF export, when Daniel says make me a PDF, I need to use a headless browser approach. The best option is Puppeteer running in your Docker container. Here's the flow: I generate the Spectacle presentation TSX, Sandpack renders it in the browser, Daniel reviews and iterates conversationally, when Daniel requests PDF I call a Node script on the backend that launches Puppeteer headless Chrome, navigates to the Sandpack preview URL, programmatically advances through each slide using keyboard events or Spectacle's API, captures each slide as a page in the PDF using Puppeteer's page.pdf method with proper dimensions, saves the multi-page PDF to the workspace, returns the file path to Daniel. The key difference from Electron is this happens server-side in Docker with Puppeteer, not client-side with Electron APIs. Your Docker container needs Chrome installed which Puppeteer can bundle, or you use Playwright which is lighter. This is production-ready, works at scale on Fly.io, and stays fully conversational. No client-side print dialogs, no Electron dependencies. Pure web stack. I should update ticket 066 with this web-first architecture instead of the Electron approach I documented. Should I revise the implementation plan for Docker and Fly.io?"

message.content: Isn't Puppeteer like a testing environment? What are you trying to say? Like you actually create a webpage and then you copy it? Isn't there a more direct approach? Can you think about this more and explain?

input.command: ./tools/src/jarvis_voice.sh --voice echo "Ah you're right to question this. Puppeteer is known for testing but it's really just a headless browser that can do anything a real browser does including generating PDFs. But you're asking a better question - is there a more direct approach than spinning up a whole browser just to make a PDF. Let me think about this differently. The problem is you have React components rendered by Sandpack in the user's browser. To make a PDF you need to either capture what's already rendered client-side or re-render it server-side. More direct approaches: Option one, html2canvas plus jsPDF entirely client-side. When Daniel asks for PDF, JavaScript in the browser captures the Sandpack iframe as canvas images, jsPDF stitches them into a PDF, downloads directly to Daniel's machine. No server involved. But this has quality issues and doesn't work well for multi-page presentations. Option two, server-side HTML to PDF without a browser. Use a library like WeasyPrint or wkhtmltopdf that directly converts HTML to PDF without running a full browser. The challenge is Sandpack output is complex React with JavaScript interactions. You'd need to extract the static HTML representation of each slide which Spectacle doesn't easily provide. Option three, and this might be what you're looking for - use React Server Components or static rendering to pre-render the Spectacle slides as static HTML on the server, then convert that HTML directly to PDF using WeasyPrint which you already have in your stack. No browser needed. The flow would be: Claude generates the presentation data as JSON or markdown, server-side React renders Spectacle slides to static HTML strings, WeasyPrint converts HTML to PDF, done. This is more direct but requires Spectacle to support server-side rendering which I'm not certain it does. Let me be honest - Puppeteer might actually be the most reliable approach despite seeming heavy because Spectacle is designed for browser rendering with animations and interactions. What's your instinct here - do you want the client-side approach with jsPDF, or should we verify if Spectacle can render server-side for the WeasyPrint approach?"
